name: Clifton James Sawit
text: Uh, disassembly is easy depending on the model. I have an old Imperator that I fixed with some wd40, but it took opening the plastic case

source_obj.text: Uh, disassembly is easy depending on the model. I have an old Imperator that I fixed with some wd40, but it took opening the plastic case

replies.text: If it's anything like what Ritchie describes, I can't do it  :p

It isn't, you just open the mouse up, find the switch corresponding to the malfunctioning button, spray WD40 into it and get into it with a brush. Check if the problem is solved before closing it back up.

Note: The WD40 (lubricant) fix works if the reason you're double clicking isn't so much as the spring getting depressed/ worn, but rather the switch (TINY button/spur which depresses said spring) snagging on the mechanism casing (again making for slower springbacks which the PC interprests as a second click). If the lubricant works you won't have to fiddle with the spring.
If lube doesn't work, then yeah spring issues
